title: Assessment of Harmful Emissions from Multiple Binder Systems in Pilot-Scale Sand Casting
reasoning: The abstract explicitly states that inorganic binders (sodium silicate and geopolymer) achieved over 90% reductions in BTEX compounds, including ethylbenzene, compared to organic systems. This indicates a clear safety advantage in terms of lower hazardous emissions, supporting these inorganic binders as safer alternatives to ethylbenzene-containing organic binders.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards associated with ethylbenzene. It only mentions that emissions of ethylbenzene (as part of BTEX compounds) were significantly reduced by using inorganic binders, implying a concern about emissions but not explicitly describing specific harms or hazards of ethylbenzene.

title: Research on the Release of Dangerous Compounds from the BTEX and PAHs Groups in Industrial Casting Conditions
reasoning: The abstract compares emissions of harmful gases including ethylbenzene from different types of moulding sands. It states that sands with inorganic binders emit significantly lower amounts of BTEX compounds, including ethylbenzene, compared to sands with organic binders such as furan resin. This indicates that sands with inorganic binders are safer alternatives in terms of gas emissions, including ethylbenzene, under industrial casting conditions.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text discusses emissions of gases including ethylbenzene during mould pouring but does not explicitly state any harms or hazards related to ethylbenzene itself.

title: Impact of Aromatic Hydrocarbons on Emissions in a Custom-Built High-Pressure Combustor
reasoning: The abstract compares emissions from ethylbenzene and other aromatic hydrocarbons, noting that ethylbenzene produced the highest unburned hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide emissions, while Indane exhibited the lowest levels of these pollutants, suggesting more complete combustion. This implies that Indane may be a safer alternative to ethylbenzene in terms of emission-related safety.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning explicitly states that ethylbenzene produced the highest unburned hydrocarbons (UHC) and carbon monoxide (CO) emissions among the tested aromatic species, indicating these as explicit harms associated with ethylbenzene combustion.

CHEMICAL HARM: high unburned hydrocarbons (UHC) emissions, high carbon monoxide (CO) emissions

title: Influence of Biodiesel on Emissions of Criteria and Non-Criteria Primary and Secondary Pollutants
reasoning: The abstract discusses biodiesel as a suitable alternative fuel that reduces emissions of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylenes (BTEX) compared to diesel. This indicates a safety advantage in terms of lower emissions of ethylbenzene when using biodiesel. Therefore, biodiesel is presented as a safer alternative to ethylbenzene-containing diesel fuel.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text does not explicitly state any harms or hazards specifically associated with ethylbenzene. It mentions changes in emissions including a reduction in ethylbenzene levels in exhaust gases when biodiesel mixtures are used, but does not describe any toxicity, persistence, bioaccumulation, or other hazards related to ethylbenzene.

title: Toxicity Threshold of Perfluorocarbon Liquids for Intraocular Use: Doseâ€“Response Assessment of In Vitro Cytotoxicity of Possible Contaminants
reasoning: The abstract identifies ethylbenzene as one of the most cytotoxic impurities in perfluorooctane (PFO) used for vitreoretinal surgery. It also reports that two substances, 5H-PFO and perfluoro-2-butyltetrahydrofuran, were non-cytotoxic at the highest tested concentrations, suggesting they have lower cytotoxicity than ethylbenzene. This indicates these substances could be considered safer alternatives to ethylbenzene in this context.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning explicitly states that ethylbenzene was one of the most cytotoxic impurities detected, reaching the cytotoxicity limit at 1.06 ppm in an in vitro cytotoxicity test according to ISO 10993-5:2009 standard.

title: Exhaust emissions of gaseous and particle size-segregated water-soluble organic compounds from diesel-biodiesel blends
reasoning: The abstract compares emissions from biodiesel blends to conventional diesel and explicitly states that adding biodiesel reduces emissions of ethylbenzene and other pollutants. This indicates that biodiesel blends are a safer alternative to conventional diesel fuels containing ethylbenzene due to lower emissions of harmful compounds.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text discusses emissions of ethylbenzene from diesel vehicles and how biodiesel blends affect these emissions, but it does not explicitly state any harms or hazards related to ethylbenzene itself.
